insights.summary: The NeuroReach VR system is a proof-of-concept mixed-reality application designed for stroke rehabilitation, focusing on enhancing arm motor control through engaging, adaptive tasks and feedback mechanisms.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system leverages mixed reality to create an intuitive and motivational environment for stroke survivors to improve arm motor control and functional recovery (c0001, d0001). It incorporates gamified elements and tasks like pouring and tracing, aligned with rehabilitation goals (c0001, d0001). The system is in its early proof-of-concept stage, with a focus on developing core functionalities and technical aspects for use with the Quest 3S headset (d0001, d0005). While promising, its clinical effectiveness and readiness for widespread application are not yet proven, and significant technical challenges remain (c0001, c0004, d0005).

I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.

provenance.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0004: The claim overstates the system's readiness for clinical application by not acknowledging significant technical challenges and limitations. The claim suggests the system has potential for clinical application in stroke rehabilitation and will showcase its capabilities. However, the evidence highlights several significant challenges that are still being addressed, including anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, inconsistent haptic support, and potential overreactive difficulty oscillation. These issues directly impact the reliability and accuracy of the system's feedback and adaptive features, which are crucial for clinical use. The evidence also mentions alternatives like running tracing without haptics or using fiducials instead of anchors, indicating that the current implementation may not be robust enough for its intended purpose without further development and validation.

insights.summary: The system employs adaptive difficulty and feedback fading to personalize the rehabilitation experience, though the implementation and validation of these features are ongoing and face technical hurdles.
insights.text: A key feature of the NeuroReach VR system is its adaptive controller, which dynamically adjusts task difficulty based on user performance to prevent overreactive oscillations and metric drift (c0002, d0002). The system also incorporates feedback mechanisms that transition from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results as the user progresses (c0002, d0002). However, the detailed implementation and effectiveness of these adaptive features are still under development and require further validation (d0002). Challenges related to the system's ability to adapt difficulty and fade feedback are acknowledged, indicating this aspect is still being refined (c0001).

Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov

I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].

feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.

The claim suggests the system has potential for clinical application in stroke rehabilitation and will showcase its capabilities. However, the evidence highlights several significant challenges that are still being addressed, including anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, inconsistent haptic support, and potential overreactive difficulty oscillation. actions.title: Validate Adaptive Controller Effectiveness
actions.detail: The adaptive controller and feedback fading mechanisms are described as key features, but their effectiveness and the proposed solutions for overreactive oscillations and metric drift require further validation. A pilot study or controlled experiment is needed to demonstrate that these adaptive features genuinely improve rehabilitation outcomes and prevent negative side effects.

actions.title: Conduct Clinical Feasibility Study
actions.detail: The system is in a proof-of-concept stage and lacks demonstrated clinical effectiveness. A pilot study with stroke survivors is essential to assess the system's intuitiveness, motivational aspects, and actual impact on motor control and functional recovery, directly addressing the lack of clinical validation.

actions.title: Clarify Dashboard Integration and Metric Derivation
actions.detail: While a projected dashboard with real-time metrics is planned, the evidence is fragmented regarding its comprehensive display and how all listed metrics ('on path', 'tilt window', 'spills proxy', 'RMS error', 'SPARC') are derived and integrated. Further clarification is needed on the dashboard's development status and the precise calculation of each metric, especially in relation to the adaptive features.

actions.title: Investigate Alternative Tracking and Haptic Solutions
actions.detail: Significant technical challenges like anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, and inconsistent haptic support persist. While solutions are proposed, the consideration of alternative approaches like fiducials for tracking and robust haptic integration strategies needs to be explored further to ensure system reliability for potential clinical use.
